section.title: U.S. T-Bills vs Canadian T-Bills
section.p: We will now look at differences between T-Bills in the United States and Canada. Recall that T-Bills are zero-coupon bonds that mature in less than one year. There are two differences between T-Bills in the U.S. and Canada. For U.S. T-Bills, we quote the yield rate as simple discount and use a 360-day year. For Canadian T-Bills, we quote the yield rate as simple interest and use a 365-day year.

Let's fix our notation before we start. Given a T-Bill, whether in the U.S. or Canada, we let N be the number of days until maturity, P the price (i.e. A(0)), C be the maturity value, and I be the amount of interest (or discount). In addition, \mathrm{QuotedRate} will be the rate of simple discount (in the U.S.) or simple interest (in Canada).

statement.p: Find a relationship between C, P, and I. This relationship is true in both the U.S. and Canada.

introduction.p: Next we find a formula for the quoted rate on a U.S. T-Bill. In the U.S., the quoted rate is a simple discount rate, and we use a 360-day year.

introduction.p: Now we will turn to a formula for the quoted rate on a Canadian T-Bill. In Canada, the quoted rate is a simple interest rate, and we use a 365-day year.
